question: Question_01_(l)
statement:
Find the absolute maximum value of
$\displaystyle f(x) = e^{x}(\sin x - \cos x )$ on the interval
$[\tfrac{\pi}{2},2\pi]$
sols:
We first take the derivative to see that

$\displaystyle f'(x) = e^{x}(\sin x - \cos x ) + e^{x}(\cos x + \sin x) = 2e^{x}\sin x$

Setting this to zero, we see that the function is zero whenever
$\displaystyle \sin x =0$ (the exponential funciton is always bigger
than 0) and on our interval $[\tfrac{\pi}{2},2\pi]$, this occurs at
$\displaystyle \pi$ and at $\displaystyle 2\pi$.

Checking the endpoints and values at the critical points, we have

$\displaystyle f(\tfrac{\pi}{2}) = e^{\tfrac{\pi}{2}}(\sin (\tfrac{\pi}{2}) - \cos (\tfrac{\pi}{2}) ) = e^{\tfrac{\pi}{2}}$

$\displaystyle f(\pi) = e^{\pi}(\sin (\pi) - \cos (\pi) ) = e^{\pi}$

$\displaystyle f(2\pi) = e^{2\pi}(\sin (2\pi) - \cos (2\pi) ) = -e^{2\pi}$

Hence, our function obtains its absolute maximum at $\displaystyle \pi$
and the value is $\displaystyle e^\pi$
hints:
Maximum values can only occur at the endpoints or critical points. Try
all these values and see which is biggest.
To take the derivative, use the product rule.
